Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of beardless man (?) wearing festival wreath. 'Grotesque' style male head, broken from a figure, with a deep furrow on the brow and the hair and the ears barely indicated; a tightly woven wreath rings the head, which was made separately from the body, with a short peg for insertion into it. It is solid; probably from a two-piece mould, with the wreath perhaps added after removal from the mould. Orange-brown Nile silt with a grey core, frequent fine gold mica, quartz and rare white inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Probably locally produced at the Naukratis terracottas workshop that was operational between the 3rd to the 2nd century BC and possibly later. A number of examples from the same or related mould series known from Naukratis Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge NA535, NA537, NA538, NA539; NA540; Fitzwilliam GR.36.1887; Ashmolean AN1896-1908-E.4758; British Museum GR1886,0401.1426; Bailey 2008, 66, no.3188, dated to the 2nd century BC). Ptolemaic parallels, probably from Alexandria (Louvre, Besques 1992, D/E 4572 Pl.87g) and favissa at Ras el-Soda, Alexandria, perhaps third to second century BC (Adriani 1952, pls 17, no. 2 and 19, no. 2, left). Adriani, A. 1952, Municipalité d’Alexandrie, Annuaire du Musée Gréco-Romain. Volume III (1940- 1950), Alexandria. Besques, S. 1992. Catalogue raisonné des figurines et reliefs en terre- cuite grecs, étrusques et romains, 4, 2. Epoques hellénistique et romaine. Cyrénaïque, Egypte ptolémaïque et romaine, Afrique du Nord et Proche- Orient. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3188)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.567) (Phase 1)
Condition: Eroded with no trace of painted decoration.
